 Review comment:
   This isn't directly relevant to this PR, but: why do we provide a version of this function which allocates from `pool`? We don't use std::string to store large quantities so it seems we could provide only
   
   ```c++
     static std::unique_ptr<Buffer> FromString(std::string data); 
   ```
   
   In the case of a string which *does* contain large data, we can use:
   ```c++
   ARROW_ASSIGN_OR_RAISE(auto buf, Buffer(large_string).Copy(pool));
   ```
   Or so

 @@ -447,14 +454,20 @@ class ARROW_EXPORT ResizableBuffer : public MutableBuffer {
 
 /// \brief Allocate a fixed size mutable buffer from a memory pool, zero its padding.
 ///
-/// \param[in] pool a memory pool
 /// \param[in] size size of buffer to allocate
-/// \param[out] out the allocated buffer (contains padding)
-///
-/// \return Status message
+/// \param[in] pool a memory pool
+ARROW_EXPORT
+Result<std::shared_ptr<Buffer>> AllocateBuffer(const int64_t size,
+                                               MemoryPool* pool = NULLPTR);
 
 Review comment:
   ```suggestion
   Result<std::unique_ptr<Buffer>> AllocateBuffer(const int64_t size,
                                                  MemoryPool* pool = NULLPTR);
   ```
   
   Since unique_ptr is convertible to shared_ptr, this will still allow
   ```c++
   ARROW_ASSIGN_OR_RAISE(std::shared_ptr<Buffer> buf, AllocateBuffer(size));
   ```
   while maintaining uniqueness of the returned buffer for anyone who doesn't wish to promote to shared_ptr.
   
   You can then deprecate the unique_ptr Status return overload as well.
